reference_citation: Garg S, Sahni D, Kumar H, et al. The segmental branching of the hepatic arteries in the liver: a cadaveric study. Anat Sci Int 94, 216â€“223 (2019).

entries.label: left artery of caudate lobe
entries.note: This entry appears to be a duplicate of row 49 (UBERON:8920039) which is already completed. Row 49 defines: 'An artery that branches from the left hepatic artery and supplies the medial portion of the caudate lobe of the liver.'
entries.recommendation: Remove duplicate entry or verify if this represents a different anatomical structure

entries.label: left lateral hepatic artery
entries.definition: An artery that branches from the left hepatic artery and supplies the left lateral lobe of the liver (segments II and III). The left lateral hepatic artery supplies the lateral portions of the left hemiliver.
entries.creator: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6757-4744
entries.justification: The paper by Garg et al. (2019) describes the segmental branching patterns of hepatic arteries. The left lateral hepatic artery is a branch of the left hepatic artery that supplies Couinaud segments II and III (left lateral lobe). This artery is consistently identified in hepatic arterial anatomy studies.
entries.anatomical_notes: Corresponds to Couinaud segments II and III of the liver

entries.label: left medial hepatic artery
entries.definition: An artery that branches from the left hepatic artery and supplies the left medial lobe of the liver (segment IV). The left medial hepatic artery supplies the medial portions of the left hemiliver.
entries.creator: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6757-4744
entries.justification: The paper by Garg et al. (2019) describes the segmental branching patterns of hepatic arteries. The left medial hepatic artery is a branch of the left hepatic artery that supplies Couinaud segment IV (left medial lobe). This artery represents an important surgical landmark for hepatic procedures.
entries.anatomical_notes: Corresponds to Couinaud segment IV of the liver

entries.label: right anterior hepatic artery
entries.definition: An artery that branches from the right hepatic artery and supplies the anterior sector of the right lobe of the liver (segments V and VIII). The right anterior hepatic artery is one of the two main sectorial branches of the right hepatic artery.
entries.vessel_supplies_blood_to_label: anterior sector of right lobe of liver
entries.creator: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6757-4744
entries.justification: The paper by Garg et al. (2019) describes the sectorial and segmental arterial branching in the right hemiliver. The right anterior hepatic artery is a major sectorial branch of the right hepatic artery that supplies Couinaud segments V and VIII (anterior sector). This branching pattern is crucial for selective catheterization procedures and hepatic surgery.
entries.anatomical_notes: Corresponds to Couinaud segments V and VIII of the liver

entries.label: right artery of caudate lobe
entries.note: This entry appears to be a duplicate of row 50 (UBERON:8920040) which is already completed. Row 50 defines: 'An artery that branches from the right hepatic artery and supplies the lateral portion of the caudate lobe of the liver.'
entries.recommendation: Remove duplicate entry or verify if this represents a different anatomical structure

entries.label: right posterior hepatic artery
entries.definition: An artery that branches from the right hepatic artery and supplies the posterior sector of the right lobe of the liver (segments VI and VII). The right posterior hepatic artery is one of the two main sectorial branches of the right hepatic artery.
entries.vessel_supplies_blood_to_label: posterior sector of right lobe of liver
entries.creator: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6757-4744
entries.justification: The paper by Garg et al. (2019) describes the sectorial and segmental arterial branching in the right hemiliver. The right posterior hepatic artery is a major sectorial branch of the right hepatic artery that supplies Couinaud segments VI and VII (posterior sector). This vessel is important for understanding hepatic arterial anatomy in the context of liver transplantation and endovascular procedures.
entries.anatomical_notes: Corresponds to Couinaud segments VI and VII of the liver

entries.label: segmental hepatic artery
entries.definition: An artery that branches from the sectorial hepatic arteries (left lateral, left medial, right anterior, or right posterior hepatic arteries) and supplies individual Couinaud segments of the liver. The segmental hepatic arteries represent the third-order branching of the hepatic arterial tree and provide blood supply to specific anatomical segments (I through VIII) of the liver.
entries.connecting_branch_of_label: left hepatic artery | right hepatic artery
entries.creator: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6757-4744
entries.justification: The paper by Garg et al. (2019) specifically focuses on evaluating the sectorial and segmental arterial branching (second- and third-order branching) in the right and left hemilivers. The abstract states that 'conventional segmental branching of both the right and the left hepatic arteries was seen in only 25% of the livers' and that the branching pattern was 'highly diverse'. Segmental hepatic arteries are crucial for procedures involving selective catheterization of individual liver segments.
entries.anatomical_notes: Third-order branches supplying Couinaud segments I-VIII; highly variable anatomy
entries.note: This is a general class representing segmental branches; specific segmental arteries (e.g., arterial supply to segments I-VIII) may require individual entries

summary.notes: Two entries (rows 97 and 136) were identified as duplicates of existing completed entries (rows 49 and 50). The remaining five entries were completed based on hepatic arterial anatomy described in the reference paper and correlated with UBERON and FMA ontology terms.
summary.paper_abstract: The purpose of this work was to evaluate the sectorial and segmental arterial branching (second- and third-order branching) in the right and left hemilivers, as knowledge of this branching should lead to improved vascular mapping for various endovascular procedures in the liver. The study was conducted on 100 formalin-fixed adult cadaveric livers. The arterial anatomy of the liver was dissected from the origin of the hepatic arteries to their segmental branches. Conventional segmental branching of both the right and the left hepatic arteries was seen in only 25% of the livers. In the remaining livers, the segmental branching of one or both of the hepatic arteries was different from that given in anatomy texts. The branching of the right and left hepatic arteries was anatomically classified into seven and six patterns, respectively, mainly on the basis of their sectorial and segmental anatomy. The present study details the highly diverse segmental arterial anatomy of the liver. The information provided here has important implications for procedures that involve selective catheterization of segmental arteries.
